title: How to Rent an Aircraft

steps.headline: Pass a medical evaluation.
steps.description: This should include a physical exam and ensure that you are healthy enough to fly. In the United States, find an Aviation Medical Examiner (AME) designated by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to conduct your evaluation.

steps.headline: Get your medical certificate.
steps.description: Make sure it is current and valid. You should have your certificate with you when trying to rent an aircraft and/or whenever you fly.

steps.headline: Sign up for flying lessons if necessary.
steps.description: The cost of renting an aircraft may be included in your flight school's lesson expenses. You may need to spend several hours flying with a flight instructor and flying solo.

steps.headline: Get your pilot's license.
steps.description: Pass all necessary written and flight tests to become licensed.

steps.headline: Find an aircraft rental company in your area.
steps.description: Try searching online or find out if your flight school also rents aircraft.

steps.headline: Read and sign a rental agreement.
steps.description: Go over any questions you have about the agreement before signing it.

steps.headline: Fill out any other required paperwork.
steps.description: A questionnaire demonstrating knowledge of piloting, a checklist for new pilots, and a form to authorize credit card charges are a few examples of other documents you may need to complete.

steps.headline: Provide proof of identification and/or renter's insurance if necessary.
steps.description: You may need to show your passport, driver's license or other accepted photo identification.

steps.headline: Pay the necessary rental fee(s).
steps.description: The rental rate may be charged by the hour. Rental prices can vary depending on the rental company's fuel, maintenance and aircraft costs.

text: Pass a medical evaluation. This should include a physical exam and ensure that you are healthy enough to fly. In the United States, find an Aviation Medical Examiner (AME) designated by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to conduct your evaluation. Get your medical certificate. Make sure it is current and valid. You should have your certificate with you when trying to rent an aircraft and/or whenever you fly. Sign up for flying lessons if necessary. The cost of renting an aircraft may be included in your flight school's lesson expenses. You may need to spend several hours flying with a flight instructor and flying solo. Get your pilot's license. Pass all necessary written and flight tests to become licensed. Find an aircraft rental company in your area. Try searching online or find out if your flight school also rents aircraft. Read and sign a rental agreement. Go over any questions you have about the agreement before signing it. Fill out any other required paperwork. A questionnaire demonstrating knowledge of piloting, a checklist for new pilots, and a form to authorize credit card charges are a few examples of other documents you may need to complete. Provide proof of identification and/or renter's insurance if necessary. You may need to show your passport, driver's license or other accepted photo identification. Pay the necessary rental fee(s). The rental rate may be charged by the hour. Rental prices can vary depending on the rental company's fuel, maintenance and aircraft costs.

This should include a physical exam and ensure that you are healthy enough to fly.
In the United States, find an Aviation Medical Examiner (AME) designated by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to conduct your evaluation.
Get your medical certificate.
Make sure it is current and valid.
You should have your certificate with you when trying to rent an aircraft and/or whenever you fly.
Sign up for flying lessons if necessary.
The cost of renting an aircraft may be included in your flight school's lesson expenses.
You may need to spend several hours flying with a flight instructor and flying solo.
Get your pilot's license.
Pass all necessary written and flight tests to become licensed.
Find an aircraft rental company in your area.
Try searching online or find out if your flight school also rents aircraft.
Read and sign a rental agreement.
Go over any questions you have about the agreement before signing it.
Fill out any other required paperwork.
A questionnaire demonstrating knowledge of piloting, a checklist for new pilots, and a form to authorize credit card charges are a few examples of other documents you may need to complete.
Provide proof of identification and/or renter's insurance if necessary.
You may need to show your passport, driver's license or other accepted photo identification.
Pay the necessary rental fee(s).
The rental rate may be charged by the hour.
Rental prices can vary depending on the rental company's fuel, maintenance and aircraft costs.
